title: 103_s470
content: There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The new section on stalking in Chapter 41 of title 18, United States Code, defines key terms like "course of conduct," "credible threat," and "harass." It outlines behaviors that constitute stalking, including a pattern of conduct directed at a specific person that causes alarm or distress. The new section on stalking in Chapter 41 of title 18, United States Code, defines key terms and behaviors that constitute stalking, including conduct that terrorizes, serves no legitimate purpose, causes emotional distress, and violates protection orders. The new section on stalking in Chapter 41 of title 18, United States Code, defines stalking as harassing or making credible threats against another person in specific jurisdictions, during interstate travel, or using interstate or foreign commerce. Offenders can face imprisonment and fines. The new section on stalking in Chapter 41 of title 18, United States Code, defines stalking as harassing or making credible threats against another person in specific jurisdictions, during interstate travel, or using interstate or foreign commerce. Offenders can face imprisonment and fines ranging from 2 to 10 years and $5,000 to $200,000. The new section on stalking in Chapter 41 of title 18, United States Code, defines stalking as harassing or making credible threats against another person in specific jurisdictions, during interstate travel, or using interstate or foreign commerce. Offenders can face imprisonment and fines ranging from 2 to 10 years and $5,000 to $200,000. The legislation also includes provisions for prosecutorial discretion, counseling as a condition of probation, and the possibility of injunctions. The legislation on stalking includes provisions for injunctions to prevent contact with the victim for up to 10 years, based on the seriousness of the offense, likelihood of reoffending, and victim safety.
